title: Advantage, Women's Tennis Association
summary: The WTA announces it is suspending all tournaments in China.. Too many Western leaders and celebrities apply a double standard when doing business with China, forgiving behavior from Beijing they'd deplore at home. Think the NBA's LeBron James on Hong Kong, or BlackRock CEO Larry Fink on governance standards for business.

title: Michigan School Shooting Suspect, Parents Met With School Officials Hours Before Attack
summary: 15-year-old boy charged as an adult on murder and terrorism charges, as a fourth student dies. School officials met with Ethan Crumbley and his parents Tuesday morning about the teen, then, several hours later, the 15-year-old opened fire with a semiautomatic handgun on his classmates, police said, in what prosecutors described as a planned shooting.

title: Will Santa Claus Visit Chuck Schumer?
summary: Traveling in a flying sleigh may be easier than passing what he wants by Christmas.. Politicians need ambition, but Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer may be taking it too far in demanding that his chamber pass the National Defense Authorization Act, federal budget, debt-ceiling increase and Build Back Better Act before Christmas.

title: 'No' on Fed Chairman Jerome Powell
summary: He's failed in his main mission, to keep the currency sound.. While Jerome Powell was a better choice than Lael Brainard for Federal Reserve chairman, that alone isn't a good reason to confirm Mr. Powell for a second term. The Senate should not support his reappointment.

title: China's Environmental Threat to Antarctica
summary: Beijing appears intent on exploiting the continent militarily and commercially.. While much of the world was focused on the recent climate summit in Scotland, China had its eye on a very different environmental issue. For the fifth year in a row, China, with Russian assistance, used an international forum to prevent the establishment of new marine protected areas along the coast of Antarctica. Beijing is increasingly interested in the southern continent, and for all the wrong reasons.

title: 'The Age of AI and Our Human Future' Review: Where Is My Thinking Machine?
summary: The next step in artificial intelligence remains largely unknown. Predicting its future implications means spinning out 'what if' scenarios.. Amazement and alarm have been persistent features, the yin and yang, of discourse about the power of computers since the earliest days of electronic "thinking machines."

title: Omicron Reinfects Government
summary: Covid strategy needs a midcourse correction. It got Joe Biden's vaccine mandate.. One might expect the Omicron variant of Covid-19 to provide useful lessons for the way governments deal with the coronavirus pandemic. It won't.

title: Alec Baldwin Says He Didn't Pull the Trigger in Fatal 'Rust' Shooting
summary: 'I would never point a gun at anyone and pull the trigger at them, never,' actor says. Actor Alec Baldwin said he didn't pull the trigger of the gun that killed a cinematographer and wounded the director on the set of the Western film "Rust."

title: Exxon to Continue Leaner Spending as Covid-19 Threat Lingers
summary: The oil giant is maintaining lower capital investment levels through 2027 and will keep focusing on cost-cutting. Exxon Mobil Corp. said Wednesday it will maintain a conservative budget for the next five years, as the outlook for oil and gas demand remains murky while coronavirus-led economic risks persist and some countries attempt to wean themselves off fossil fuels.

title: 'Aquatint: From Its Origins to Goya' Exhibition Review: Drawing Made Dreamy
summary: The labor-intensive method of reproducing ink and wash drawings gets a close examination at the National Gallery.

title: 'The Nutcracker' Ballet Review: Slightly Grown Up, Still Glorious
summary: New York City Ballet's holiday perennial returns after a Covid-19-induced absence, with a few pandemic tweaks in place.

title: Disney Elects Susan Arnold as Board Chairman, Replacing Robert Iger
summary: Iger's reign at the helm of Disney's board comes with his departure at the end of the year. Walt Disney Co. 's board of directors has elected Susan Arnold its new chairman, replacing Robert Iger, the longtime chief executive who is set to depart from the company later this month.

title: Capital One Is Latest Bank to Ditch Overdraft Fees
summary: Lender will stop charging $35 for overdrafts and nonsufficient funds early next year. Capital One Financial Corp. said it will stop charging customers overdraft fees, making it one of the largest banks to do so.

title: Stacey Abrams to Run for Georgia Governor
summary: Democrat announces candidacy three years after losing to Brian Kemp in razor-close race. Stacey Abrams said she is running for governor of Georgia for a second time.

title: A Biden Vaccine Mandate Puts Patients at Risk
summary: Washington's threat to withhold Medicare and Medicaid funding is likely to do more harm than good.. The Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services is threatening to withhold payments to healthcare facilities unless they require the Covid-19 vaccine for their workers. This action is misguided. I am vaccinated and support the goal of increasing vaccination rates. But the CMS policy has the potential to backfire and jeopardize patient access, safety and the quality of care for millions of Americans.

title: Supreme Court Majority Shows Openness to Mississippi Abortion Law
summary: State's law banning procedure after 15 weeks of pregnancy presents direct challenge to 1973 Roe v. Wade. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court's conservative majority sharply questioned the propriety of constitutional protections for abortion rights dating back almost five decades as the justices heard arguments over the most significant abortion case in a generation.

title: What to Watch: The 13 Best New Movies and TV Shows From November
summary: A deep dive into the Beatles, Will Smith as the Williams sisters' father, Tom Hanks after the apocalypse, and more.. Here's a roundup of the month's most noteworthy movies and TV shows, as covered by The Wall Street Journal's critics.

title: The Politics Behind 'Ain't We Got Fun?'
summary: A timeless tune still resonates amid our economic stresses.. Most pop songs are sincere confessions of love sought, lost or acquired. Yet every decade seems to spawn one or two humorous novelty blockbusters. A nascent radio star in 1947, Arthur Godfrey scored big with "Too Fat Polka." In 1969 Ray Stevens spun a jaunty, guitar-playing King of the Jungle into "Gitarzan" gold. When "The Treasures of Tutankhamun" exhibition toured the world, Steve Martin cashed in with "King Tut," which he performed in 1978 on "Saturday Night Live" in culturally appropriating faux-Egyptian regalia.

title: California Prepares for More Water Restrictions as Drought Worsens
summary: The state plans to virtually eliminate the water it supplies to local communities, which are running out of alternatives. Californians may face new restrictions, including fines for improperly washing their cars, as the state prepares to virtually eliminate the water it supplies to local communities as it grapples with an unrelenting drought.

title: Stocks Fall as Omicron Fuels More Volatility
summary: Investors struggle to assess implications of coronavirus variant on business, economies. U.S. stocks fell in a volatile trading session Wednesday, dragged down by news that the first known case of the Omicron variant was identified in the U.S.

title: House Passes Bipartisan Bill to Speed Judges' Financial Disclosures
summary: Legislation, approved by a 422-4 vote, follows WSJ investigation into judges' financial conflicts; Senate bill pending. WASHINGTON-Federal judges would have to speed disclosure of stock trades and publish their financial-disclosure reports online for the first time under a bipartisan bill overwhelmingly passed by the U.S. House Wednesday.

title: With Higher Rates on the Horizon, Some Pandemic-Favorite Stocks Are Suffering
summary: Stocks like Snap, Zoom and Peloton have slid in recent months. The prospect of higher interest rates is diminishing investors' appetite for riskier corners of the stock market.

title: Maxwell's Lawyers Challenge Accuser's Memory of Sexual Abuse
summary: Jeffrey Epstein's longtime companion is on trial for allegedly helping disgraced financier sex traffic and abuse underage girls. A lawyer for Ghislaine Maxwell tried to cast doubt on an accuser's testimony at the British socialite's sex-trafficking trial on Wednesday, challenging the woman's memory and showing inconsistencies with earlier statements she made to federal investigators.

title: First U.S. Omicron Case Identified in California
summary: Infected person, a San Francisco resident, returned from South Africa on Nov. 22, CDC says. The first known case of the Omicron variant in the U.S. was identified in a San Francisco resident who recently returned from South Africa, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and California health officials said.

title: Square Changes Its Name to Block
summary: New name for financial-services company aligns with its chief's interest in bitcoin and blockchain. Square Inc., the financial-services company co-founded and led by former Twitter Inc. chief Jack Dorsey, is changing its corporate name to Block Inc.

title: Government Shutdown Deadline Nears as Deal Eludes Lawmakers
summary: Democrats and Republicans haggle over details of funding extension, with vaccine politics potentially slowing progress. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers worked Wednesday to reach an agreement on a short-term spending patch to avoid a potential partial government shutdown this weekend, with Democrats and Republicans still haggling over the details of the funding extension.

title: Patchy Cyber Data Makes Policy Success Difficult to Gauge
summary: Lack of consistent breach reporting makes it difficult to tell if hacks are increasing or decreasing, government officials say. Despite months of new regulations, policy changes and law-enforcement actions targeting ransomware groups based in Russia and elsewhere, government officials say it isn't clear if their efforts are working because private companies don't report every attack.

title: Five Publishers Sue Shopify Over 'Textbook Pirates'
summary: McGraw Hill, Pearson claim e-commerce company should be responsible for policing its customers; Shopify says it takes actions against sellers that violate its policies. A group of five educational publishers sued Shopify Inc., claiming the e-commerce company is liable for the unauthorized school textbooks, test packs and solutions manuals sold by websites using Shopify's online tools.

title: The Passengers Who Have the Toughest Time Flying
summary: Travelers in wheelchairs often find planes more inaccessible than other forms of transportation. If you faced a one in 50 or even one in 100 chance of losing your ability to move through life independently when you took your next flight, would you take that chance?

title: Democratic Rep. Peter DeFazio Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Transportation Committee chairman's retirement after 36 years comes as Democrats face challenging midterms. WASHINGTON-Rep. Peter DeFazio, the chairman of the House Transportation Committee, said he won't seek reelection, becoming the latest Democrat to retire ahead of what is expected to be a difficult midterm election as the party tries to hold on to its House majority.

title: Big Tech's Liability Shield Is Under Siege
summary: Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen is among witnesses at House hearing. WASHINGTON-House lawmakers signaled Wednesday they would press forward with legislation to make internet platforms more accountable to online users, in what is expected to be a showdown between Washington and Silicon Valley.

title: In A World... (Thursday Crossword, December 02)
Biden Says Shelves Will Be Stocked for Holidays Despite Supply Backlogs
summary: Republicans say president's policies contributed to high prices; Biden says it is 'easier to complain about a problem than to fix it'. WASHINGTON-President Biden said that prices for everything from groceries to gas remain high but sought to assure Americans that his administration is tackling supply logjams.

summary: A remake of 'Diary of a Wimpy Kid' hits Disney+, Tracy Oliver channels 'Sex and the City' for the new series 'Harlem,' and more to add to your queue. Here's where to stream it all:

title: Supply Imbalances Continued to Hold Back U.S. Growth This Fall, Fed's Beige Book Says
summary: Businesses report 'persistent difficulty in hiring and retaining employees' as labor shortage continued. The U.S. economy grew at a "modest to moderate" pace this fall, with supply-chain issues and labor shortages holding back growth despite strong demand, the Federal Reserve said Wednesday.

title: Covid-19 Cases Nearly Double in South Africa as Omicron Reaches More Countries
summary: Resume Subscription. Newly reported cases of Covid-19 almost doubled Wednesday in South Africa, the country with the highest number of identified cases of the new Omicron coronavirus variant, as the U.S. reported its first case of the strain in someone who had returned from a trip to the country.

title: Don't Forget the Victims of 'Victimless Crimes'
summary: I am still haunted by the visit of a mother about to lose her son to a drug overdose.. In "San Franciscans Get What They Voted for With Chesa Boudin" (Cross Country, Nov. 27), Michael Shellenberger mentions that the San Francisco district attorney had campaigned in part on lenient handling of "victimless crimes." Among those crimes he considered "victimless" were open drug use. For me, this recalled an incident some years ago involving a client.

title: Inflation Sends Sen. Warren on a Wild Turkey Chase
summary: Blind to the economics, the Massachusetts senator blames poultry executives for the higher cost of your Thanksgiving dinner.. Regarding "Stupid Inflation Tricks" (Review & Outlook, Nov. 29): By far the greatest factor in the cost of raising a turkey (or a pig or nearly any other meat animal) to market size is the price of the grain the animal eats. Because of rising world demand and so-so global production levels, the prices of corn and soybeans have jumped over 50% in the last two years. Meat prices reflect that cost increase.

title: Hannah Arendt Knew Adolf Eichmann Deserved to Die
summary: The author of 'Eichmann in Jerusalem' unequivocally supported the death penalty for the architect of the Holocaust.. Norman Lebrecht, in reviewing two books on the life and thought of Hannah Arendt (Nov. 6), claims that "By law and logic, she felt, [Adolf Eichmann] was unworthy of capture, trial, or execution." But in "Eichmann in Jerusalem," Arendt supported all three. She unequivocally supported the death penalty, writing, "Because he . . . had played a central role in an enterprise whose open purpose was to eliminate forever certain 'races' from the surface of the earth, he had to be eliminated."

title: Annuity Offers Certainty for Retirement, but There's a String Attached
summary: A simple comparison of initial payments shouldn't be the last word.. The letter (Nov. 20) from James H. Szostek of the American Council of Life Insurers about the so-called "4% rule" makes the valid point that an annuity from an insurance company guarantees more annual retirement income than a standard withdrawal strategy. Not noted was that the typical annuity also guarantees that none of that original $1 million investment will be returned after death-even if you receive only a few annuity payments.

title: Woke or Proto-Totalitarian?
summary: For people like me, who grew up in a communist country, we can feel it in our bones.. I cheered while reading Garry Kasparov's op-ed "'Woke' Is a Bad Word for a Real Threat to American Democracy" (Nov. 18). For people like me, who grew up in a communist country, his assessment of the current trend in American politics reflects what we know from firsthand experience. We can feel it in our bones. Shutting down debate, marginalizing and canceling people, denying free and open expression of opinions, destroying people indirectly or directly, is the way totalitarian regimes gain and maintain power.

title: We All Pay Extra for Ethanol
summary: A fair comparison must be based on heating value.. C. Boyden Gray contends in his letter (Nov. 23) that ethanol is less expensive than gasoline. His comparison is made gallon for gallon. A fair comparison, however, would be based on heating value. When burned, regular gasoline yields approximately 115,000 British thermal units of heat per gallon. Ethanol yields 75,700 BTU a gallon. Now, factor in the prices cited by Mr. Gray. Gasoline selling for $2.28 a gallon costs $1.98 per 100,000 BTU. Ethanol selling for $2.20 a gallon costs $2.91 per 100,000 BTU.

title: How SoftBank Vision Fund Values Its Portfolio Holdings
summary: The fund relies on 18 people and a lot of technology to value its investments. SoftBank Group Corp. is investing billions of dollars in startups and later-stage companies around the world. The Vision Fund, which is based in London, holds stakes in about 250 companies. Keeping track of what they are worth is a crucial task for the fund's managers.

title: Supply-Chain Snarls Hit Production of Trailers Needed to Haul Goods
summary: Manufacturers can't get their hands on materials to make semitrailers, despite high demand from trucking companies. summary: This stucco mansion in the Hamptons was built in 1909. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

summary: The capital city has one of the hottest high-end real-estate markets in the country, with entry-level list prices for the top 5% of the market hitting $2.34 million in 2021, a rise of nearly 33% over 2020 prices. summary: The public school system is failing. My philanthropy will give $750 million to a proven alternative.. American public education is broken. title: James Patterson's Dream Writing Partner? Putin or the Pope
summary: The bestselling author on his journey to the top, crossing paths with James Taylor at a psychiatric hospital and some of his favorite objects.. James Patterson gets annoyed at being called prolific. "I love that word," he says sarcastically, though it's hard to find a better adjective to capture the more than 300 books he's written since 1976 (averaging almost seven every year). Most have been bestsellers, making him one of the wealthiest living authors, earning about $80 million in a year, according to the most recent estimate by Forbes. His debut novel, The Thomas Berryman Number, earned him an Edgar Award. In 2019, he won the National Humanities Medal.

summary: A ruling issued in Louisiana questions constitutionality of administration's requirement. A federal judge issued a temporary nationwide block against a Biden administration mandate that millions of healthcare workers get vaccinated against Covid-19 starting next week.

title: Andre Dickens Wins Atlanta Mayor Race, Faces Rising Crime Problem
summary: Outgoing Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms chose not to seek reelection after protests, violence. ATLANTA-Voters elected City Councilman Andre Dickens as Atlanta's next mayor in a runoff election Tuesday, after a campaign dominated by concern over a rise in violent crime in Georgia's largest city.

title: U.S. Weighs Stricter Covid-19 Testing for Travelers
summary: Rules would require a negative test within 24 hours of boarding a flight to the U.S.. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is weighing stricter Covid-19 testing requirements for travelers entering the U.S., including U.S. citizens, to slow the spread of the emerging Omicron variant.

title: Merck's Covid-19 Pill Backed by FDA Advisers
summary: Oral antiviral pill was recently found to be 30% effective at reducing risk of hospitalization and death in high-risk people. An outside panel of scientific advisers to the Food and Drug Administration narrowly recommended the agency authorize the experimental Covid-19 oral antiviral from Merck & Co. and partner Ridgeback Biotherapeutics LP.

title: CNN Suspends Chris Cuomo Indefinitely
summary: Network said records released Monday by the office of the New York attorney general 'raise serious questions'. CNN suspended prime-time anchor Chris Cuomo indefinitely after records released this week by the New York attorney general's office provided a detailed look into his efforts to help his brother, former New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, respond to allegations of sexual misconduct.

title: Investigators Authorized to Search Weapons Supplier in 'Rust' Shooting
summary: New affidavit describes how reloaded ammunition or live bullets from practice may have ended up on set. A new affidavit released by authorities Tuesday offered the first possible explanations of how live ammunition ended up in a revolver fired by Alec Baldwin in a fatal shooting on the set of the film "Rust."

title: Dr. Oz Enters Race for GOP Senate Seat in Pennsylvania
summary: Celebrity surgeon is among several candidates seeking to replace retiring Sen. Pat Toomey. Celebrity surgeon Mehmet Oz filed paperwork Tuesday to run for an open Senate seat in Pennsylvania, further scrambling a crowded GOP primary field in a state that could determine which party wins control of the Senate in next year's midterm elections.

title: GOP Lawmakers Trade Insults on Twitter in Latest Intraparty Blowup
summary: Marjorie Taylor Greene questions the conservatism of Nancy Mace, prompting an emoji-laden comeback. WASHINGTON-Two prominent first-term Republican lawmakers publicly traded insults and argued over their conservative bona fides on Tuesday, just as party leaders have tried to quell dust-ups that have tested GOP unity.

title: Judge Questions If Purdue's Sacklers Abused Bankruptcy System
summary: A judge considering whether to overturn a $4.5 billion settlement between Purdue Pharma and the Sacklers said she has serious concerns about distributions to family members. The federal judge weighing the $4.5 billion settlement between Purdue Pharma LP and the Sackler family members who own the OxyContin maker said she had serious concerns about whether they abused the bankruptcy system by collecting billions of dollars from the company before it filed for chapter 11 protection.

title: Sic 'Transitory' Gloria Fed
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell finally abandons the word to describe 6% inflation over the last year.. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell finally jettisoned the word "transitory" to describe today's inflation, and we suppose it's better late than never. Asked by Sen. Pat Toomey on Tuesday how long inflation would have to persist before the Fed no longer considers it to be transitory, Mr. Powell abandoned the word.
